title: Waltz in A minor (Chopin)
text:
<a href="Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric%20Chopin">Frédéric Chopin</a>'s Waltz No. 19 in <a href="A%20minor">A minor</a>, <a href="List%20of%20compositions%20by%20Fr%C3%A9d%C3%A9ric%20Chopin%20by%20opus%20number%23Works%20without%20opus%20numbers">B</a>. 150, <a href="Krystyna%20Kobyla%C5%84ska">KK</a> IVb/11, <a href="J%C3%B3zef%20Micha%C5%82%20Chomi%C5%84ski">P</a>. 2/11, is a <a href="Waltz%20%28music%29">waltz</a> for solo <a href="piano">piano</a>. The waltz was written sometime between 1843 and 1848, but was not published until 1860, after the composer's death, by Jacques Maho. At this time, it was attributed to <a href="Charlotte%20de%20Rothschild">Charlotte de Rothschild</a> and was published as No. 3 of "Four pieces for piano". This collection also included Chopin's <a href="Nocturne%20in%20C%20minor%2C%20Op.%20posth.%20%28Chopin%29">Nocturne in C minor, B. 108</a>. It was not until 1955, 95 years after its initial publishing, that it was correctly attributed to Chopin.
Structure.
This waltz is structured as a single <a href="Movement%20%28music%29">movement</a> in <a href="rondo">rondo</a> form marked <a href="Tempo%23Basic%20tempo%20markings">allegretto</a>. It is one of Chopin's shortest and technically easiest waltzes.
Analysis.
The piece shows great sadness, while enclosing some episodes that hint at happiness and hope. The first <a href="Theme%20%28music%29">theme</a> of the piece uses a simple but effective melody, conveying a sad portrait, with decorative <a href="Ornament%20%28music%29">ornaments</a> used throughout. The second theme is more lively, punctuated by a brisk ascending arpeggio, although it still has a certain sadness. About halfway through the piece, there is a <a href="Modulation%20%28music%29">modulation</a> into <a href="A%20major">A major</a>, featuring a happy and joyful melody. The piece concludes with the main theme, followed by a short <a href="Coda%20%28music%29">coda</a>.
